concern:
I'm planning on going back to college in May for the summer semester after a 7 year long break. I'm trying to finish all my prerequisites within these next 2 semesters if possible.

These will be the classes that i'm planning on taking

Human Anatomy and Physiology with the lab,
Intermediate Algebra,
Ethics, and
American Government

The summer semester is 12 weeks instead of 15 weeks, i've been seeing alot of people saying that they usually only do 6 credit hours for summer so i'm wondering if 14 is too much?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! What's on your mind today? I'm here to listen and offer support.
I'm feeling anxious about returning to college after a long break and managing a potentially overwhelming schedule. I want to make sure I can handle it without burning out.

It's completely understandable to feel anxious about the transition back to college. It sounds like you're really trying to be proactive about managing your schedule and taking care of yourself. Have you thought about any strategies that might help you stay on top of things without getting overwhelmed?

I've thought about creating a detailed weekly schedule to break down my tasks into smaller, manageable parts, which could help me avoid feeling overwhelmed. Additionally, I'm planning to incorporate regular breaks and selfcare routines to maintain my mental health during this transition back to school.

Those are fantastic ideas! It sounds like you're already taking some great steps towards managing your workload and prioritizing your mental health. When do you plan to start implementing your weekly schedule and selfcare routinesbefore classes start or during the first week?

I plan to start implementing my weekly schedule and selfcare routines before classes begin in May, so I can ease into the routine and reduce any initial anxiety. This way, I'll be better prepared to handle the demanding 12week semester without feeling overwhelmed right from the start.

Smart thinking! Starting early can definitely help you establish good habits before the semester gets too busy. It sounds like you're already anticipating potential challenges. Have you thought about any specific selfcare activities you'd like to incorporate into your routine?

I've thought about incorporating daily walks and short meditation sessions into my routine to help me unwind and recharge. These activities should help me maintain my mental balance and prevent burnout as I ease back into college life.

That's a really wise approach! Daily walks and meditation can be incredibly beneficial for mental health and stress management. Remember, consistency is keyeven on busy days, try to make time for these selfcare practices. Do you have any other support systems in place for when you're feeling overwhelmed, like friends, family, or campus resources?

Yes, I have my family and friends for emotional support when things get tough, as well as campus resources like the therapists to help me stay balanced and avoid burnout during my return to college. I'm also considering reaching out to academic advisors if I need guidance with my schedule.
